docs.snippet: Visitors to the Sunshine State this summer are being greeted by a new slogan: ''Florida in Flames.'' Since Memorial Day, thousands of wildfires have burned about a half million acres of mostly forest land and threatened some communities. But even ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Visitors to the Sunshine State this summer are being greeted by a new slogan: ''Florida in Flames.'' Since Memorial Day, thousands of wildfires have burned about a half million acres of mostly forest land and threatened some communities. But even with intermittent road closures and evacuations of residents, and cancellation of Fourth of July events in some areas, it's been business as usual at most attractions, parks and beaches, state tourism officials said -- even under a blanket of smoke. Everglades National Park in southern Florida, Miami-Dade County beaches and Walt Disney World in Orlando reported no commercial impact from the blazes as of early July, even when some had operated under hazy skies from distant fires.
docs.abstract: Article on impact on Florida's tourist industry of thousands of wildfires that have burned since Memorial Day; most hotels and attractions report no drop in attendance or cancellations; worst disruptions are in northeast region (M)

headline.main: Florida Tourism Goes On Despite Blanket of Smoke

headline.main: Customs Bureau Postpones Ban On Free Entry of $1-to-$10 Gifts; More Inspections Planned Orders Solicited

byline.original: By EILEEN SHANAHAN Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: IT is probably fair to say that if Paris were not normally such a safe city a recent spate of terrorist bombs would not have been so disturbing. Parisians -- and visitors to Paris -- are used to feeling secure here. And now, metaphorically speakin...
docs.lead_paragraph: IT is probably fair to say that if Paris were not normally such a safe city a recent spate of terrorist bombs would not have been so disturbing. Parisians -- and visitors to Paris -- are used to feeling secure here. And now, metaphorically speaking, they have to look over their shoulders. This has changed the city's mood perceptively. True, many proud Parisians say they won't be intimidated and are responding with sang-froid to the terrorist menace, but there is no ignoring the new security measures that are now everywhere to be seen.

docs.snippet: IN mid-December, the first American ship to dock in Cuba in almost 40 years arrived in Havana with a shipment of food from the United States. A number of cruise lines based in the United States would like to have been sailing right behind that shi...
docs.lead_paragraph: IN mid-December, the first American ship to dock in Cuba in almost 40 years arrived in Havana with a shipment of food from the United States. A number of cruise lines based in the United States would like to have been sailing right behind that ship, the Express, but for now their executives can only wait and wish. Among them is Sven Lindblad, the founder of Lindblad Expeditions. ''In 1995, our director of environmental affairs was invited to Cuba to look around,'' Mr. Lind blad said. ''He was excited at what he saw, and we developed some itineraries so that when it was legal to go, we wouldn't be starting from scratch.''
docs.abstract: American cruise lines continue to covet lines with itineraries to Cuba, noting that September 11 terrorist attacks have made Cuba even more inviting; several European and Canadian companies already offer low-cost package tours; handfull of cruise ships that dock in Cuba have been prohibited from visiting US for next six months and Bush administration is unwilling to ease its policies against island; photo (M)

headline.main: Cuba, So Close, Remains Distant for Cruise Lines

docs.snippet: OBSCURED by headlines about El Nino and Western Europe's latest gyrations toward a single currency is the news that a large chunk of European travel culture is heading for extinction.    Duty-free shopping, a practice born in Ireland half a centur...
docs.lead_paragraph: OBSCURED by headlines about El Nino and Western Europe's latest gyrations toward a single currency is the news that a large chunk of European travel culture is heading for extinction. Duty-free shopping, a practice born in Ireland half a century ago that gradually spread to airports and ferry slips around the world, spawned an immense mobile shopper's world by permitting travelers to buy all sorts of things -- including cigarettes, liquor and perfumes -- without paying local duties and taxes.
docs.abstract: European Union maintains that Europe is now one market, and by middle of 1999 there will be more more duty-free purchases in Europe; wave of protest has risen not only from companies directly involved in duty-free shopping business but also from European tourism and transportation industries; these companies and industries argue that end of duty- and tax-free shopping will eliminate tens of thousands of 140,000 jobs in Europe that depend on manufacturing and selling duty-free products; they say by drying up revenues to airlines and airports and ferry operators, it will lead to higher costs that will crimp investment and have to be passed on to consumers in form of higher fares (L)

docs.snippet: AMERICANS who hoped that visiting Cuba as tourists might become less complicated saw those hopes evaporate last weekend when President Clinton signed a bill that, among other things, codifies the existing restrictions on United States tourists. Th...
docs.lead_paragraph: AMERICANS who hoped that visiting Cuba as tourists might become less complicated saw those hopes evaporate last weekend when President Clinton signed a bill that, among other things, codifies the existing restrictions on United States tourists. The bill also prevents the president or his successors from changing the prohibitions without the approval of Congress. But for all the Congressional huffing and puffing over passage of the bill, tour operators say things are not likely to change much, if at all. Naturalized American citizens born in Cuba will still be allowed to travel there, as apparently will Americans who go as part of humanitarian, educational or athletic groups. Just about the only people likely to be affected by the legislation are Americans not born in Cuba who want to travel there on their own rather than in groups. And Americans who might otherwise have gone to Cuba illegally may decide not to, rather than test the United States government's resolve to enforce the newly codified law.
docs.abstract: Article on travel to Cuba in light of Pres Bill Clinton's recent signing of bill that codifies existing restrictions and prevents Clinton or his sucessors from changing prohibitions without Congressional approval; photo (M)

headline.main: Traveling to Cuba Is as Tricky as Ever

docs.snippet: LEAD: The Justice Department said today that Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, concerned over a recent trip to Japan by former Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and five department officials, would impose a new policy to bar official trips unless th...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The Justice Department said today that Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, concerned over a recent trip to Japan by former Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and five department officials, would impose a new policy to bar official trips unless they relate directly to an employee's work.

headline.main: CONCERN ON MEESE PROMPTS TRIP BAN
